etymology.description: Phonetic: 牙(牙) (yá, "tooth") + Semantic: 邑(邑) (yì, "town; city") = originally a place name 琅邪 -> borrowed for 'wrong; evil'
etymology.interpretation: The character 邪(yé, 'wrong') originated from its use in place names, with the phonetic 牙(yá, 'tooth') suggesting sound and the semantic 邑(yì, 'town; city') indicating its geographical associations. Over time, this character was borrowed to represent the idea of wrongness or evil.

examples.chinese: 有人散布邪说(有人散播邪說)。
他相信真理(他相信真理)，拒绝邪观点(拒絕邪觀點)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiāngxìn zhēnlǐ, jùjué yé guāndiǎn.
examples.english: He believes in the truth and rejects wrong views.

examples.chinese: 流言蜚语常常掺杂邪成分(流言蜚語常常摻雜邪成分)。
examples.pinyin: Liúyán fēiyǔ chángcháng chānzá yé chéngfèn.
examples.english: Rumors are often tainted with wrong elements.
